data.title: ‎‘Three Crowns of the Sailor’ review by Redfern • Letterboxd
data.meta_description: Never trust a sailor, he said. They’ve grown too accustomed to the flat surface of the open sea. So how can you trust someone with no depth? And have you ever noticed how each place looks exactly the same when you’re out there on the boat? But, of course, that means that each place is not the same. Raúl Ruiz was a sailor, he was a great friend of Borges and Carroll too. Each were storytellers, and like all good storytellers the words fell out of their mouths landing with a splash on the floor. You know, words are indispensable to sailors;
data.text: Never trust a sailor, he said. They’ve grown too accustomed to the flat surface of the open sea. So how can you trust someone with no depth? And have you ever noticed how each place looks exactly the same when you’re out there on the boat? But, of course, that means that each place is not the same. Raúl Ruiz was a sailor, he was a great friend of Borges and Carroll too. Each were storytellers, and like all good storytellers the words fell out of their mouths landing with a splash on the floor. You know, words are indispensable to sailors; they use them like boats to row across a changing series of faces and places, each point belonging to its past and future. Now I have told you the secret of language and the sea—don’t forget it until it forgets you.
